title: The boom of coffee business in Melbourne: Does citizens' age and income drive this trend?
text: Coffee culture significant part Melbourne’s lifestyle. city known vibrant coffee scene, plethora cafes coffee shops scattered throughout city. recent years, number cafes Melbourne rise, new cafes opening every day. driven factors behind trend? cafeMel package aims provide useful data sets functions explore growing patterns industry whether census information can forecast trends.

title: The boom of coffee business in Melbourne: Does citizens' age and income drive this trend?
text: released version cafeMel Github can installed running following code:

title: The boom of coffee business in Melbourne: Does citizens' age and income drive this trend?
code: library(cafeMel) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(tibble) library(kableExtra) library(sf) library(gridExtra)

what: High concentration of cafe shops in central Melbourne suburbs
title: The boom of coffee business in Melbourne: Does citizens' age and income drive this trend?
text: overall map shows number cafes Melbourne increasing years. central suburbs, Melbourne CBD, Carlton, South Yarra witnessed highest concentration cafes period. Observing trend, interesting explore whether age income distribution citizens domain suburbs correlation number cafes. package provides functions visualize number cafes every suburbs specific year. function map_plot takes year argument returns map chart showing number cafes Melbourne suburbs selected time.
code: vic_coffee_map |>    group_by(Location) |>   ggplot() +   geom_sf(aes(fill = cafe_count), color = "black", size = 1) +   theme_void() +   facet_wrap(~census_year) +   scale_fill_viridis_c() +   labs(title = "Number of cafes in Melbourne suburbs", fill = "Cafe count") map_plot(2021)

what: Age and income distribution of Melbourne citizens
title: The boom of coffee business in Melbourne: Does citizens' age and income drive this trend?
text: package also includes census data Melbourne citizens 2016 2021. data set contains information median age median income citizens suburb. following code snippet shows age income distribution Melbourne citizens 2021.
code: vic_coffee_21 <- vic_coffee_map |>    filter(census_year == 2021) |>    left_join(census_suburb, by = "Location") |>    select(- c("Median_age_16", "Median_income_16"))|>   arrange(desc(cafe_count)) vic_coffee_21 |>    ggplot(aes(x = Median_income_21,               y = cafe_count)) +    geom_point(aes(color = Location))  +   labs(x = "Median income",         y = "Number of coffe shops",        title = "Income distribution of Melbourne citizens in 2021 (compared with cafes count)") +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "none")

title: The boom of coffee business in Melbourne: Does citizens' age and income drive this trend?
text: cafeMel package provides clean data set simple functions explore coffee business Melbourne. package allows users visualize concentration cafes Melbourne suburbs age income distribution citizens. However, improve user experience, updated data sets relevant information combined provide valuable insights analysis.

what: Explore the coffee business in Melbourne suburbs
title: Explore the coffee business in Melbourne suburbs
text: cafeMel package build context instruction course ETC5523-2024: Communication Data. package simple package provides functions explore data coffee business Melbourne period 2002 2022. interactive shiny app also included package help users explore census data information coffee shops, observing correlation special characteristic industry.

title: Explore the coffee business in Melbourne suburbs
text: install development version cafeMel package GitHub, follow code:

title: Explore the coffee business in Melbourne suburbs
text: example gives overview map Melbourne suburbs locations.
code: library(cafeMel) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(sf)  vic_coffee_map |>    group_by(Location) |>   ggplot() +   geom_sf(aes(fill = Location), color = "white", size = 1) +   geom_sf_text(aes(label = Location), size = 2.5) +   theme_minimal() +   theme(axis.title.y = element_blank(),          axis.title.x = element_blank()) +   labs(title = "Melbourne Suburbs Map")
